articles.headline: Benjamin Lawsky, Sheriff of Wall Street, Is Taking Off His Badge
articles.snippet: Mr. Lawsky, the New York State regulator, is said to be departing in June to start his own legal and consulting firm.
articles.abstract: Mr. Lawsky, the New York State regulator, is said to be departing in June to start his own legal and consulting firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a grim few years for the banks that Benjamin M. Lawsky regulates. He threatened to pull their licenses, fined them hundreds of millions of dollars and forced dozens of their employees to resign.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: In Kentucky, Republican Primary Yields Disarray
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell faces the prospect of having to embrace a former foe, Matt Bevin, who is in a tight Republican primary race with James R. Comer.
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell faces the prospect of having to embrace a former foe, Matt Bevin, who is in a tight Republican primary race with James R. Comer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Matt Bevin, a wealthy Louisville businessman and Tea Party favorite, tried to unseat Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, in the Kentucky primary last year, Mr. McConnell vowed to “crush them everywhere” — meaning the Tea Party and Mr. Bevin. He did.

articles.headline: Export-Import Bank Near Showdown in Congress
articles.snippet: Powerful Republicans are bent on letting the export credit agency die, imperiling overseas projects and sales by American companies.
articles.abstract: Powerful Republicans are bent on letting the export credit agency die, imperiling overseas projects and sales by American companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2013, the impoverished African nation Cameroon teamed with General Electric and the Environmental Chemical Corporation, which is based in Burlingame, Calif., to begin work on a $668 million drinking water project for its thirsty capital, financed with loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank of the United States.

articles.headline: For Drivers, Confusion Reigns in Takata Airbag Recall
articles.snippet: Automakers on Wednesday were still sorting out which cars needed to be included in the expanded recall of cars with Takata airbags, leaving many consumers with more questions than answers.
articles.abstract: Automakers on Wednesday were still sorting out which cars needed to be included in the expanded recall of cars with Takata airbags, leaving many consumers with more questions than answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When millions of Americans woke up Wednesday morning to go to work, many asked themselves a simple question: Is my car safe to drive?
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: U.S. to Send Rockets to Iraq for ISIS Fight
articles.snippet: Obama officials have called the fall of Ramadi a huge setback, but have sought to quell critics in the region with the deployment of weapons, which are expected to arrive in early June.
articles.abstract: Obama officials have called the fall of Ramadi a huge setback, but have sought to quell critics in the region with the deployment of weapons, which are expected to arrive in early June.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is rushing 1,000 antitank rockets to the Iraqi military to help combat the massive suicide vehicle bombs that Islamic State militants used in capturing the provincial capital of Ramadi, a first step as the Obama administration weighs a range of difficult options to help its beleaguered ally.

articles.headline: Puffy, Feathered Sticking Point of a $612 Billion House Bill
articles.snippet: The attempt to circumvent protections for the sage grouse, as well as those for the lesser prairie chicken, is part of a push by House Republicans to roll back environmental regulations.
articles.abstract: The attempt to circumvent protections for the sage grouse, as well as those for the lesser prairie chicken, is part of a push by House Republicans to roll back environmental regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Bruce Westerman, an Arkansas Republican, spoke for many Americans this week when he conceded during a House hearing that he had never laid eyes on a sage grouse. Had he seen one, he surmised, he would have thought “a bobwhite quail got friendly with a Dominecker hen.”

articles.headline: Frantic Message as Palmyra, Syria, Fell: ‘We’re Finished’
articles.snippet: In Palmyra and Ramadi, Iraq, the Islamic State carried out a strategy of attrition, weakening the opposition for a crushing strike.
articles.abstract: In Palmyra and Ramadi, Iraq, the Islamic State carried out a strategy of attrition, weakening the opposition for a crushing strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army soldier had long served in Palmyra, but he was on leave when he heard that Islamic State militants had attacked a village northeast of the desert city, killing dozens of his comrades. He sent frantic text messages, trying to reach them. No one answered.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Food Companies Fear Bird Flu May Cause Egg Shortages
articles.snippet: The flu is forcing farmers to kill more than 38 million infected birds, 33 million of which are laying hens.
articles.abstract: The flu is forcing farmers to kill more than 38 million infected birds, 33 million of which are laying hens.
articles.lead_paragraph: With avian flu devastating a significant portion of the nation’s egg-laying hens, major food companies and restaurant chains are bracing for shortages and scouting the country to find alternative supply sources.

articles.headline: CVS Health Agrees to Buy Omnicare in $12.7 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: The deal is expected to expand CVS’s prescription drugs business for long-term care facilities as it seeks to capitalize on the aging U.S. population.
articles.abstract: The deal is expected to expand CVS’s prescription drugs business for long-term care facilities as it seeks to capitalize on the aging U.S. population.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the American population gets older, pharmacies and other health care providers are increasingly positioning themselves to capitalize and serve the needs of this demographic. This group often needs drugs for chronic conditions like diabetes and heart disease, as well as lifesaving medications for sudden conditions like infections or pneumonia.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Chad Bray

articles.headline: This Time, Senate Votes to Advance Trade Pact
articles.snippet: The Senate will now vote on a series of amendments, some highly controversial, before a final vote on President Obama’s ambitious trade agenda.
articles.abstract: The Senate will now vote on a series of amendments, some highly controversial, before a final vote on President Obama’s ambitious trade agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A flurry of last-minute deal-making on the Senate floor Thursday rescued President Obama’s ambitious trade agenda from defeat, advancing legislation that would empower the president to complete a sweeping, 12-nation Pacific trade accord.

articles.headline: Despair, and Grim Acceptance, Over Killings by Brazil’s Police
articles.snippet: While deaths at the hands of officers have set off fevered protests around the United States, they are often seen in Brazil as a normal fixture of policing.
articles.abstract: While deaths at the hands of officers have set off fevered protests around the United States, they are often seen in Brazil as a normal fixture of policing.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Eduardo de Jesus was on his doorstep in Complexo do Alemão, a vast maze here of cinder block homes, when his mother heard the loud blast of gunfire.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Taylor Barnes

articles.headline: Essays About Work and Class That Caught a College’s Eye
articles.snippet: Few students applying to college write about their family financial situations. But those who take the risk — whether poor or well-off — can stand out from the crowd.
articles.abstract: Few students applying to college write about their family financial situations. But those who take the risk — whether poor or well-off — can stand out from the crowd.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of the 1,200 or so undergraduate admission essays that Chris Lanser reads each year at Wesleyan University, maybe 10 are about work.
